message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of puffy eyes, dark urine, and a recent sore throat suggest a possible diagnosis of IgA nephropathy (Berger’s disease). The characteristic finding on renal biopsy for this condition is sub-epithelial electron dense deposits. Linear Ig deposits along the basement membrane are found in Goodpasture syndrome, podocyte fusion is seen in minimal change disease, and no abnormalities are seen in nephrotic syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest an acute episode of IgA nephropathy, also known as Berger's disease. The most likely finding on renal biopsy would be sub-epithelial electron dense deposits. Linear Ig deposits along the basement membrane are seen in Goodpasture syndrome, not IgA nephropathy. No abnormalities would not explain the symptoms. Podocyte fusion on electron microscopy is seen in minimal change disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of bilateral periorbital edema and dark urine suggests nephrotic syndrome. The most likely finding on renal biopsy for nephrotic syndrome is sub-epithelial electron dense deposits on electron microscopy (EM). Linear Ig deposits along the basement membrane are seen in Goodpasture syndrome. No abnormalities would not explain the patient's symptoms. Podocyte fusion on EM is seen in minimal change disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest the possibility of an autoimmune disease such as IgA nephropathy or membranous nephropathy. Among the options, Sub-epithelial electron dense deposits on electron microscopy are most commonly seen in membranous nephropathy, which often presents with nephrotic syndrome and periorbital edema.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest nephrotic syndrome, and among the options, the most likely finding on renal biopsy for this patient is sub-epithelial electron dense deposits. Linear Ig deposits are seen in Goodpasture syndrome, no abnormalities are not expected, and Podocyte fusion is seen in minimal change disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the most likely diagnosis is post-infectious glomerulonephritis. In this condition, sub-epithelial electron dense deposits are found on renal biopsy. Linear Ig deposits along the basement membrane are seen in Goodpasture's syndrome. Podocyte fusion is seen in minimal change disease. No abnormalities on renal biopsy would not explain the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest the most likely diagnosis is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. Sub-epithelial electron dense deposits are the classic finding on renal biopsy for this condition. Linear Ig deposits along the basement membrane is seen in Goodpasture's syndrome, podocyte fusion on electron microscopy is seen in minimal change disease, and no abnormalities is not a likely finding for a patient with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of nephrotic syndrome, which can be caused by various renal conditions such as minimal change disease, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, and membranous nephropathy. Of these options, sub-epithelial electron dense deposits are most commonly associated with membranous nephropathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of puffy eyes and dark urine suggest nephrotic syndrome. The most likely finding on renal biopsy for this condition is sub-epithelial electron-dense deposits on electron microscopy. The other options are associated with different forms of glomerulonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with IgA nephropathy, a common glomerular disease in children that often follows an upper respiratory tract infection. On renal biopsy, the most likely finding is sub-epithelial electron dense deposits. Linear Ig deposits along the basement membrane are seen in Goodpasture syndrome. Podocyte fusion on electron microscopy is seen in minimal change disease. No abnormalities on renal biopsy would not explain the patient’s symptoms.
